Topic.Title: Alibaba Group IPO in 2013

Message.Msg: No one thinks Alibaba Group will wait until 2015 but I hope they do. The longer Alibaba waits the more Yahoo will cash in on Alibaba's tremendous growth. Yahoo shareholders can't lose!

Topic.Title: Alibaba Group IPO in 2013

Message.Msg: Some sort of partial or whole #Alibaba IPO next year# has been a rumor for 5 years or more. Rumor in the sense that nobody from Alibaba, not even anonymous sources, have mentioned it as a possibility. Rumor in the sense that only Yahoo longs have mentioned it as a possibility. Today Jack Ma controls Alibaba Group. After an IPO that might not be the case since he will not hold a controlling interest and the new Alibaba Group public company board of directors might chose some other CEO. Jack Ma has nothing to gain by Alibaba Group going public, but much to lose. He would not be the first founder to be kicked out of his company after going public. And I am also sure he has no burning desire to become the Jerry Yang and David Filo of Alibaba Group.

Topic.Title: Alibaba Group IPO in 2013

Message.Msg: I think what YHOO and Alibaba agreed upon as stated in the letter of agreement is that likely IPO is mid next year but Alibaba has the right to be the first buyer of YHOO stakes if YHOO decided to sell it. For obvious reasson, like many said here, the longer Jack Ma hold off the IPO the better for YHOO getting a good premium. Ken Goldman will maximiize YHOO Asian investment getting every penny premium. YHOO to mid $20's.

Topic.Title: Alibaba Group IPO in 2013

Message.Msg: The only mention of an IPO and a date in the letter of agreement is; #If a Qualified IPO has not occurred by December 31, 2015, Yahoo! shall only be required to sell such Shares as it owns at the time of a Qualified IPO.# And anyone who remembers AliPay does not think that waiting is good for anybody other than Jack Ma. --Take the money and run or Jack Ma will do it-- is a valid concern.

Topic.Title: dr. gloom has little credibility left as he has been proved wrong.....

Message.Msg: Nobody stating bare facts has any credibility with the clique of $28 Yahoo longs. #All Jack Ma has to get from an AG IPO is many billions of dollars for himself and AG to work with#....Who gets the money from an IPO? Not the company. An IPO does not give AG any money to work with and why should Jack Ma give AG the public company his money? Is the cash Yahoo gets from an AG IPO going to AG? Did Zuckerberg and other owners get rich or did Facebook get the money from that famous IPO? #And why would any AG board- at least for the forseeable (5 years) future-not want Ma as CEO after the way he has grown AG# There is never any shortage of people who think they can do better than anyone else. Why did Apple get rid of Steve Jobs? Why is Jerry Yang no longer the head of Yahoo? Sandy Lerner, Cisco Systems? Diane Greene, VMware? Richard Thalheimer, the Sharper Image?

Topic.Title: Facebook to Buy Yahoo!; Why not? Makes sense to me since my wife visits Facebook all the time and I use Yahoo! all the time. Facebook users i'm sure are already posting things from yahoo sites.

Message.Msg: uh...Facebook is growing....Yahoo isn't. That is how stocks are valued. Not by how much cash is on hand. Therefore if a company has smaller revenue but is rapidly growing while another company has higher revenue but is not really growing then the faster growing company deserves a higher valuation. If you do not know this then please don't quit your day job....LOL. You really shouldn't be trading stocks.

Topic.Title: Facebook to Buy Yahoo!; Why not? Makes sense to me since my wife visits Facebook all the time and I use Yahoo! all the time. Facebook users i'm sure are already posting things from yahoo sites.

Message.Msg: I retired at age 54 due to my investing prowess. I shorted FB at the IPO because I know it was overhyped and retail investors were being gorged. As far as Yhoo I have been accumulating for three years since the realization of the Alibaba potential. My ave cost is $13, and I now have 65,000 shares. Facebook is growing? Perhaps, but I think GS and the gang overhyped it. The FB IPO as actually a secondary offering if you ger my drift, but you probably didn't even know that. Yahoo has always had more viewership than FB and they stay longer. FB could still be a fad. Yahoo has been around for a while and now under Mayer seem to be restarting it revenue growth and relevance on the web. Inho Yahoo is steady and rising vs still a gamble for FB. Let me know if you want a dissertation on how to retire early.

Topic.Title: Update on feedback and action taken by message board team

Topic.Title: Facebook to Buy Yahoo!; Why not? Makes sense to me since my wife visits Facebook all the time and I use Yahoo! all the time. Facebook users i'm sure are already posting things from yahoo sites.

Message.Msg: I won't get into your discussion with Dickey_Betts but Yahoo DOESN'T have more viewership than Facebook...Yahoo's has been pegged optimistically at 700M for quite sometime whereas FB has over 1B, 900M if you include fake profiles but I assume the same would hold true for Yahoo, knocking it to the 630M range. I just seen a special on FB, and they're growing a 100M users per quarter. As for time spent between the two properties its not even close, last I checked. It wasn't too long ago Yahoo users went from 3hrs to 2:15hrs in a single quarter. Facebook has something like 600M users login in EVERY DAY and of those they average 22hrs per month. Can't remember specifics but it was released in the past few weeks. Just found this: Statistics One billion monthly active users as of October 2012. Approximately 81% of our monthly active users are outside the U.S. and Canada. 584 million daily active users on average in September 2012. 604 million monthly active users who used Facebook mobile products as of September 30, 2012. ***While I could research more its the holidays after all, specifically the Hitwise or Comscore or SearchEnglineland answer to time spent online my question pertains to how $40 is a good deal for an acquirer. I posted my numbers, a few days ago, and giving AG an IPO valuation of $70B and later stake of $150B valuation I for the life of mean can't make a case for over $30 per share. If they cash out all their stuff, the core isn't worth multiples of its revenue, just isn't. As for "growth", I suggest you click on slide 4 from the latest earnings cause I see the words "flat YOY", 1% growth and 2% growth. Remember the online advertising market is growing far faster than that AND Yahoo had double digit declines from 09' on. They need 50% growth just to get to 08' levels essentially. Slide 12 goes like this $9.4B for cash(7.4B once Uncle Sam gets a $2B check), 954M Accts Rec., 309 deferred revenue, $7.7B on Yahoo Japan, and 8.1B for AG stake. $24.463B/1.2=$20.39 per share. I feel like Santa, haven't counted for taxes, but let's say that last AG stake is worth TRIPLE($24.3B) but that is an additional $16.2B in value/1.2B shares= $13.5+20.39= $33.89. I don't think the core is worth that $7 per share. If I apply a 35% tax rate to that 7.7B+24.3B=$32B(AG+Yahoo Japan) it falls to $20.8B, a loss of $10B or $8 per share to taxes. So now instead of $7 to reach your $40 it is now $15 for the core...are you telling me the core is worth $15 per share while also TRIPLING the value of the last AG stake???
